poem:
**Dourie Farm**

On the hill, they graze,  
Holstein-Jersey crossbreeds,  
their black-and-white flanks  
mirrored by the Irish Sea.  
  
Foreign hands, once tenders,  
now ghosts in soil and sky—  
fields whisper their loss,  
the future's uncertain tide.  

Looming clouds 
hold Scotland's breath;  
silent, still, on the brink.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Foreign staff have ‘changed our lives’: Scottish farmers fear for future after changes to skilled worker visas A group of dairy cows are grazing on a grassy slope overlooking the Irish sea, a picture-postcard scene that wouldn’t be out of place on a VisitScotland advert. These are just some of the 1,200 Holstein-Jersey cross cows kept at Dourie Farm, perched on the hill above Port William in Dumfries and Galloway in the south-west of Scotland.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
